description.plain: Ultramagnetic MC’s are an often-overlooked hip-hop group that achieved the peak of their popularity in the mid-to-late 1980s with their classic album, Critical Beatdown. Composed of Ced Gee, Kool Keith, DJ Moe Love, and TR Love, Ultramagnetic MC’s (often referred to as, “MCs Ultra”) are still active today, the group’s latest album—The Best Kept Secret—being released in 2006.

songs.full_title: Ego Trippin' (Original 12" Version) by Ultramagnetic MC's (Ft. Ronnie T)
songs.title: Ego Trippin’ (Original 12" Version)

description.plain:
Released in 1986, it is Ultramagetic MC’s first 12". Along with the likes of “I Ain’t No Joke” and “PSK, What Does It Mean???” it ushered in a pioneering approach to Hip Hop

With the recognizable breakbeat, this is a first of many records to sample Melvin Bliss’s slept-on gem “Synthetic Substitution”

songs.full_title: Kool Keith Housing Things by Ultramagnetic MC's
songs.title: Kool Keith Housing Things

description.plain:
An introduction to Kool Keith and primarily his only solo cut on Critical Beatdown. The track shows his versatility in his skill with imaginative wordplay he would later become well known for. The song presents his early braggadocio and competitive style in which he wasn’t afraid to take shots at Hip Hop royalty such as Rakim, Slick Rick and Grandmaster Flash. With this style, it would lay the blueprint and coincide with him briefly using the alias “Rhythm-X” on the follow-up album Funk Ya Head Up in 1992.

The track for many is mostly remembered for being featured in the 1999 PS1 video game Thrasher: Skate and Destroy which also featured east coast hip-hop legends such as EPMD, Afrika Bambaataa and Stetsasonic.

songs.full_title: Bust the Facts by Ultramagnetic MC's
songs.title: Bust the Facts

description.plain:
Bust the Facts is  a superb evocation of the block party era with Keith imagining he’d been a performer not just an attendee, he introduces himself as “the best emcee in the world” at the start of this song. On this record he refers some of early pioneers and sounds of the breakdance/dj/b-boy/MC era, with a another sly dig thrown in to Kool Moe Dee’s style, whom he had earlier dissed on this record with “Pluckin Cards”

It could be stated that Kool Keith did a sequel to this track entitled “1977” on the Dr. Octagoncologyst LP.
